misconfigurations.alert_criteria: iam keys have not been rotated in X days

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS account root user does not have MFA enabled or enforced
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Root account has no MFA device registered or root account accessed without MFA challenge
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable hardware MFA (U2F security key) for root account and implement mandatory MFA enforcement policy
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: As announced at re:Inforce 2025, AWS now enforces MFA for root users across all account types. The root account has unrestricted access to all resources. Without MFA, a compromised password grants complete account control. Hardware MFA (U2F security keys) provides stronger protection than virtual MFA apps. Root account credentials should be stored in a physical safe and only used for account recovery.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS re:Inforce 2025: Mandatory MFA enforcement for root users announced

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon GuardDuty threat detection is not enabled in all regions
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: GuardDuty is disabled in one or more AWS regions with no threat detection monitoring active
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable GuardDuty in all AWS regions and configure centralized log aggregation using AWS Organizations
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Amazon GuardDuty provides intelligent threat detection by continuously monitoring AWS accounts for malicious activities using machine learning. Without GuardDuty enabled, threats like unauthorized access, compromised credentials, and cryptocurrency mining go undetected. GuardDuty monitors CloudTrail events, VPC Flow Logs, and DNS logs to identify suspicious behavior patterns.
misconfigurations.notes: Announced at AWS re:Inforce 2025 with enhanced EKS runtime monitoring capabilities

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to ensure his CDN is secure
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Update the CDN to use valid cyphers from TLS 1.2/1.3

misconfigurations.scenario: Application credentials and API keys are hardcoded instead of using AWS Secrets Manager
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Secrets are stored in environment variables, configuration files, or hardcoded in application code
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Migrate all secrets to AWS Secrets Manager with automatic rotation enabled and KMS encryption
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Hardcoded secrets in code, configuration files, or container images are a critical security vulnerability. AWS Secrets Manager provides encrypted storage with automatic rotation capabilities and audit trails. Secrets Manager integrates with RDS, Redshift, DocumentDB, and other services for automatic credential rotation, eliminating the need to update application code when rotating secrets.
misconfigurations.notes: Secrets Manager provides automatic rotation for supported AWS services

misconfigurations.scenario: Public-facing applications do not have AWS WAF protection enabled
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Application Load Balancer, API Gateway, or CloudFront distribution has no WAF association and no protection against OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS WAF with managed rule groups for OWASP protection, IP rate limiting, and geo-blocking
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS WAF protects web applications from common exploits like SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and DDoS attacks. Without WAF, applications are vulnerable to automated attacks and zero-day exploits. AWS Managed Rules provide continuously updated protection against emerging threats. WAF can be deployed on CloudFront, ALB, API Gateway, and AppSync.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Managed Rules provide protection against OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Security Hub is not enabled to aggregate security findings
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Security Hub is not enabled and no centralized security posture management exists
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS Security Hub to aggregate findings from GuardDuty, Inspector, Macie, and third-party security tools into a unified dashboard
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS Security Hub aggregates security findings from multiple AWS services and third-party tools, providing a comprehensive view of your security posture. Without Security Hub, security teams must manually check multiple services, leading to missed vulnerabilities and delayed incident response. Security Hub includes automated compliance checks against standards like CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark, PCI-DSS, and AWS Best Practices.
misconfigurations.notes: Enhanced at re:Inforce 2025 with improved threat signal analysis

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Config is not enabled to track resource configuration changes and compliance
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: AWS Config is disabled with no configuration history tracking and compliance violations going undetected
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS Config with managed rules for CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark and organizational security policies
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS Config continuously monitors and records AWS resource configurations, enabling compliance auditing, security analysis, and change tracking. Without Config, unauthorized changes go unnoticed and compliance violations remain undetected. Config integrates with Security Hub to provide compliance status against multiple standards and can automatically remediate non-compliant resources using Systems Manager.
misconfigurations.notes: Config integrates with Security Hub for compliance reporting and Systems Manager for auto-remediation

misconfigurations.scenario: Mission-critical applications lack AWS Shield Advanced DDoS protection
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: CloudFront distributions or ELBs handling critical traffic without Shield Advanced and no DDoS cost protection or 24/7 response team access
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS Shield Advanced for critical resources and configure DDoS Response Team (DRT) access for 24/7 support during attacks
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS Shield Standard provides basic DDoS protection, but Shield Advanced offers application-layer protection, cost protection against DDoS-related charges, and 24/7 access to the AWS DDoS Response Team. Critical applications handling financial transactions, healthcare data, or serving millions of users should use Shield Advanced to ensure availability during sophisticated DDoS attacks.
misconfigurations.notes: Shield Advanced includes cost protection and access to AWS DDoS Response Team

misconfigurations.scenario: ECS task definitions are configured with unsafe defaults including public IPs, privileged mode, or plaintext secrets
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: ECS tasks assigned public IP addresses when not required, containers running in privileged mode, or secrets passed as plaintext environment variables
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Configure ECS tasks without public IPs in private subnets, disable privileged mode, use Secrets Manager for credentials, and enable read-only root filesystems
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: ECS task misconfigurations create significant security risks. Public IP assignments expose containers directly to the internet. Privileged mode grants containers host-level access. Plaintext secrets in environment variables can be extracted by anyone with task describe permissions. Security Hub includes checks for these misconfigurations and AWS recommends using private subnets with NAT gateways, non-privileged containers, and Secrets Manager integration.
misconfigurations.notes: Security Hub provides automated checks for ECS task definition misconfigurations

misconfigurations.scenario: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) templates are not scanned for security vulnerabilities before deployment
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: CloudFormation, Terraform, or CDK templates not scanned and CI/CD pipeline lacks IaC security scanning
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable Amazon Inspector Code Security in CI/CD pipelines to scan IaC templates, application code (SAST), and dependencies (SCA) before production deployment
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Amazon Inspector Code Security (GA at re:Inforce 2025) provides shift left security by scanning Infrastructure as Code templates, application source code (SAST), and open-source dependencies (SCA). This identifies misconfigurations, vulnerabilities, and security issues before they reach production. Inspector integrates with CodePipeline, GitHub Actions, and GitLab CI to automatically scan pull requests.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS re:Inforce 2025: Amazon Inspector Code Security now Generally Available

misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks each Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) security group for an excessive number of rules. If a security group has a large number of rules, performance can be degraded

misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks each Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) security group for an excessive number of rules. If a security group has a large number of rules, performance can be degraded

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to be made aware of the locations of all public s3 buckets (or their contents)
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: bucket or its subfolders are open to the public
misconfigurations.recommendation_action:
- Randomise your bucket names! There is no need to use company-backup.s3.amazonaws.com.
- Set appropriate permissions and audit regularly.  
- If possible create two buckets - one for your public assets and another for private data.
- Try Amazon Macie - it can automatically classify and secure sensitive data.

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon EKS clusters do not have GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection enabled
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: GuardDuty EKS Runtime Monitoring is not enabled with no threat detection for containerized workloads
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection for EKS to monitor container runtime behavior and detect threats in Kubernetes environments
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Announced at re:Inforce 2025, GuardDuty now provides runtime threat detection for EKS clusters. This monitors container behavior, Kubernetes API calls, and pod-level network activity to detect threats like cryptocurrency mining, privilege escalation, and lateral movement. Without this protection, compromised containers can operate undetected.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS re:Inforce 2025: GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection for EKS announced
